captions.text:
There's a lot of information 
out there about carving.

These days you can buy carving skis, 
carving gloves, carving underpants,
we're going to clear up some of these misconceptions

and make it nice and easier 
for you to understand.

A pure carved turn is a turn where the ski
is gripping and biting and the shape of the

ski is turning you, and this is the important
bit - there is no skidding.

The moment you have skidding in your turn 
it is no longer a carved turn.

Skidding is important in your everyday skiing
but we are going to focus just on the carving.

So while we're on the subject of carving,
let's take a closer look at the ski.

The ski is thinner in the middle 
than it is at the top and the bottom.
The skis creating an hourglass shape.

When I put that onto the edge, 
it's actually going to start to bend

and that is what is going to
take me round.
It's not a new idea, skis have had sidecut,

which is what it's called, 
for over a hundred years.
If I put the ski onto the edge,

you're going to notice that there's a gap here
through the middle of the ski.
If I then put pressure and push through it,
you can see the ski bending and flexing and

it's that that's going to
take you round the corner.

I'm on the edge and the shape 
of the ski is making me turn.
In this turn the skis are skidding, creating resistance and
it's not a carved turn.

I've found myself a nice, easy slope, all
I'm going to do is start to slide across and

roll those knees and ankles
in towards the slope.

It starts easy, and then 
I'm going to gently build it up.

Feet hip width apart,
hands nicely in front, and from here

I can just gently roll the skis on, I'm not trying
to turn, just feel the skis turning you.

It's all about trust, as I roll onto the
edge the ski will turn.

All I've done here is come slightly higher
on the slope, my skis are going to be pointing

more downhill, but I'm doing
exactly the same thing.

Start to slide down, now just feel those
edges biting, but don't try and do too much,
just let it happen smooth.

I'm spending more time pointing 
down the hill picking up speed
but it's the same movement.

I've come even further up the hill and 
we're going to complete a whole turn.

The trick is to be patient at the start. 
Feel the ski engage,
and what I mean by that is feel the edge,

and then just gradually build it up 
through the turn.
So I'm starting to slide in, really smooth,

feel the skis come round, and gently build
the edge through the turn.
This is now a complete turn.

I'm on one set of edges, then roll the
skis flat, feel the new edges engage and start to turn.
Remember. Be patient.
A great way to feel the skis engage is to use a gentle slope
and then just roll the knees and ankles from side to side.

It's a very subtle movement, but an effective way
to feel the ski working.

This is a great slope just to practice rolling
those knees and edges into the slope.

You'd probably just go straight down here, 
so use it for training.

As your feel for the ski improves, you can
start to link the turns and pick up the speed.

A patient start to the turn 
will stop the ski skidding,
roll the edges on gently and let the skis work.
All the things we've looked at there will help you in your general skiing,

it's not just about carving. 
Try not to draw a massive line

between carving and everything else,
feeling that nice, strong edge, helping you

come round the corner, is a general skill
that you're going to use all around the mountain,

and as it gets steeper you're going to have
to replace a percentage of that carve with

a skid, but make it a nice progressive, controlled
skid, and even if the ski is skidding,

the ski is still bending and helping you go round
the corner. That's carving.

title: Carving - How to Carve on Skis - Advanced Ski Lesson #6.2

comments.author: Henrik Simonsen

comments.text:
Hi again +Henrik Simonsen. 
Before learning how to carve on skis you'd want to have a mastered a strong 
dynamic parallel turn. 

Make sure you have a good strong skiing stance. Feet hip width apart, 
standing centred with your hands in front.  If your stance is too narrow 
you'll easily tip over and loose balance. If it is too wide then it'll be 
difficult to roll both edges on together.    Have a look at the 7 Sins film 
and see if there is anything familiar: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n19QmFC2qVc&list=PLA893DD2FE6198306&index=11

To start out with get up a bit of speed on a gentle slope where you have 
space, feel comfortable and are in control. Try rolling the edges over 
gradually, nothing is rushed.  Try small bits at a time and build it up, 
rolling the edges over a little more each time.  

You'll need enough speed to allow this to happen but not too much that you 
feel out of control.  Ski within you limits and as we always say get the 
basics right first and it will make the rest of your progression flow much 
easier. 

Hopefully these pointers help you learn how to carve on skis.
Cheers

progression so don't rush in. Get the basics right first and it will make 
carving a lot easier.  I think the best place to start would be to look 
through out Ski School Intermediate films, especially using Turn Shape to 
control your speed.  Have a watch and if you have any questions or comments 
just ask:  
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M4_HZfGTunw&index=3&list=PLA893DD2FE6198306. 
 Hope this helps your skiing.
comments.author: Elate Media

comments.text:
This is all so wrong - and on so many levels that it is hard to know where 
to begin. The skier/instructor shows little to no upper body coordination 
(in this and other videos) and basically leans uphill to establish any edge 
angles. The concept of leaning uphill while square to the skis and leading 
with the outside arm and inside ski (versus counter acting and counter 
balancing with an actively tipping, lightened, and pulled back inside foot) 
will only lead to terminal skills that will fail in more advanced skiing. 
This is the way the PSIA tried to make us teach about 20 years ago. There 
are much better models out there. Check out Harald Harb videos or even 
World Cup videos of Marcel Hirscher or Anna Fenninger for comparison and 
decide for yourself. This whole series is unfortunately flawed.﻿

comments.author: Elate Media

comments.text:
While skidding is not carving, a skier can drift their ski within a carve.  
Particularly the front half of the ski drifting specifically in the top 
half of the turn.
This action is the foundation of effective mogul skiing.  When a skier does 
drift their tips in the top of the arc, momentum is diminished leaving the 
skis slow in the fall line so when they are in the bottom half of the arc 
they are slow and need no braking action to control speed.

Carving can be exhilarating and fun, but it is overrated in the big 
picture, unless of course if all a skier wants to descend is groomer 
terrain.  Taking to steeps and bumps, slipping snow from the edge in a 
drift is far easier and safer than pure carves.﻿

comments.author: Sergio Parreno

comments.text:
Great video and series!  I teach (L2 PSIA) and am a MasterFit Certified 
bootfitter for a local shop.  There is another point that is crucial and I 
have not seen it in recent comments.  A skier's boot setup must be accurate 
for him or her to be able to get on edge and carve as efficiently as Darren 
is doing in this video.  By setup I am mostly referring to the cuff 
adjustment and sole cant (if required) to achieve a 0.5-1.5 degree inside 
biase from a flat on the snow ski.  A large number of skiers at all levels 
are unaware of their own setup.  If your boots are biased to ride the ski 
on the outside edge (or way too much on inside) - and LOTS of folks suffer 
from one of these hindrances, you will plateau on your learnings and find 
it very difficult to achieve a carving edge.  Mainly because the outside 
ski in a turn will require too far a distance for the ankle and knee to 
travel to the inside to be efficiently and easily put up on edge.  Darren's 
subtle moves to carve can only be achieved thru a proper cant setup.  So, 
if you're stuck in skidding and can't seem to get to this carving place, 
have your setup checked by a qualified bootfitter.  And again, Thanks 
Darren for this series...I hope my teaching is as clear to my students as 
yours is to me.
((
 ))
((
 ))﻿

comments.author: Hans Doijer

comments.text:
You forgot the phantom foot movement. In our ski school we have a direct to 
parallel teaching system where we cut out the wedge and have them start 
skiing parallel. One of the foundations of carving turns is tipping yours 
skis as you explained and lightening your inside foot. This will 
drastically increase your turn radius. Also for more advanced carving don't 
forget counterbalance and counter rotate.﻿

comments.author: Edward Moss

comments.text:
Good video. ONE VERY IMPORTANT NUANCE... At 1:42 you mention "roll those 
knees and ankles in toward the slope". While it might seem unimportant, it 
is critical to understand the ANKLES BEGIN TO ROLL FIRST and lead the 
knees!  The ankle roll into the boot is that which creates leverage inside 
the boot and consequently the solid connection to the ski (that's what 
you're seeing with "powerful" skiers).  Another important thing to note is 
how high in the turn Darren is beginning the carve.  A really good carved 
turn carves the top of the turn as well as the middle and the bottom.﻿

comments.author: Marielle Mullon

comments.text:
I think so, the day my edges started to grip on te snow, I was hooked :) 
The modern ski is designed to make carved turns. Because the ski has 
sidecut, makes it bend when put on edge and the ski will follow a curved 
path in the snow. By doing so, your turns become more round, you can take 
turns at higher speeds (no slowing down by skidding), they require less 
effort. You'll ski more efficiently.I don't know all the technical stuff 
and the forces which apply, I only know how to do it and how to teach it :) 
And: when becoming more advanced and you feel that first rebound at the end 
of a turn, it's heaven :) Very addictive. And yes, you can switch faster 
between edges, therefore being very useful in short turns. The forces which 
are created by your movements and the ski make the transitions fast and 
efficient. I think this covers your questions.

comments.author: steve kiak

comments.text:
I constantly changes throughout your turn. The earlier you can put pressure 
on your future outside ski, the higher your level of skiing. I 
progressively increase the pressure throughout the turns with a high-low 
movement and weight balance. Towards the end of my turn, in the steering 
phase, pressure on my ski's is approx. 80-20. In the transitions phase, 
pressure is gradually and progressively shifted towards my future outside 
ski. by the time my ski's are pointed downhill, it's 50/50. Of course this 
is dependent on the type op turn. When I do long carved turns, I almost put 
100% of my weight on the outside ski, otherwise, centripetal force will 
throw my body out of the turn :) For years I skied on 1 ski all the time, 
putting all my weight on the outside ski. The inside ski was basically 
hanging there. The day my instructor and examinator started doing routines 
on skiing on both ski's, a whole new world opened up :) Transitions happen 
much faster, because your losing less time on shifting weight, the inside 
ski also gripped, balance improved, stance improved, no more lifting the 
inside ski to start the next turn, etc. Style improved too :) So basically, 
in my experience, the slower I go, there's less shifting of weight. The 
faster I go, it's necessary to put a lot of weight on the outside ski, to 
resist centripetal force. I'm now the lowest level ski instructor. Some 
more words of advice from higher educated skiers?

ski or how to link one turn to the next. Phrases like "Trust your skies" do 
nothing for altering behaviors. Your speech in the lesson is both vague and 
useless. You, obviously, know how to carve, but your "lesson" does little 
in the way of actually teaching the skill. Beef up the specifics and lose 
the fuzzy for a more helpful film.﻿
comments.author: Gyntster

comments.text:
One five-minute video cannot explain everything. This is clearly just an 
introduction to the basic idea of carving. Watch some of the other videos 
if you want specific body positioning, but you gotta start somewhere.
comments.author: Marielle Mullon

comments.text:

comments.author: Michael Biittner

comments.text:
What silly comments you have. I've been following what this instructor is

comments.author: Bert Tougas

comments.text:
Indeed, and I have witnessed countless ski instructors leading a line of 
students making all sorts of mistakes, and that instructor never looks back 
to help. Diagnosing and correcting issues is impossible with that sort of 
instruction. The best way to teach is to model a few turns, and then have 
your students ski down one at a time such that you may critique and advise, 
but this rarely happens. Currently, I am struggling to get my inside ski 
carving as deeply as my outside ski,  because I am an old "A-Frame" racer 
from the 70's. The best tips I'm working with are: Bow-legged inside leg 
and transfer all weight to the inside ski about half way through the turn. 
What do you have for me?
comments.author: Gyntster

comments.text:
+Gyntster Less talk, more skiing. This is a good visual that many people 
can use. Most "instructors" talk it to death.
comments.author: Michael Biittner

comments.text:
+aboutface102
I see your point, but a good instructor will deliver  crisp behavior for 
their client to pay attention to, like "Position your hands as if holding a 
big Pilates ball in front of you, and do that for this entire run." This 
gives the student one thing to adhere to. There is no need to droll on. The 
film "drolls on" with rhetoric that is not behavior specific, and that is 
where I made a case for more information. "Be bowlegged with the inside 
ski", "Drill both knees into the new turn", "Crush walnuts in the shins of 
both boots during the turn", "Do not advance the inside ski", "Hold hands 
up, relaxed and in the direction of the turn", "Press your rib into the hip 
of your turning leg"...these are all behavior specific comments that would 
actually implement real instruction. Just sayin'...
comments.author: Gyntster

comments.text:
Obviously this is a truncated version of a full lesson, or a summary. I've 
had instructors like the ones you are talking about and after about 10 
minutes of them drolling on about hand position I left to go skiing. It 
should be simple and fun, not like doing your taxes.
comments.author: aboutface102

comments.text:
When I try this, I have trouble keeping the skis parallel. One always cuts 
in more than the other and wants to take me over. Any advice for this? P.S 
GREAT video!﻿
comments.author: htimsnad2793

comments.text:
This could be a result of any number of things, but it's possible that your 
weight is not far enough forward. If you are leaning too far back, it's 
hard to control the direction of your skis and they might diverge a bit. 
There's a lot more front to your ski than back, so it makes sense to use 
the front of the ski to initiate your turns.
comments.author: Marielle Mullon

comments.text:
+JMfromCA I'm a professional ski racer and you should have 70% of your 
weight on the downhill ski and 30% on the uphill ski if you want to carve 
properly.
comments.author: justchillin360

comments.text:
+LessTraveled Gravel if you weight the downhill ski you will skid more.
In carving especially (and most upper level skiing) one needs to think in 
different terms.
In relation ship to the turn think about outside and inside ski instead. At 
the beginning of the turn start to balance on and edge the outside ski 
(this will be the uphill ski at that point) as we move through the middle 
of the turn the edge will be at its highest angle. Through the end of the 
turn (now the outside ski will become the downhill ski) and into the 
transition to the new turn we should decrease the edge angle as to smoothly 
change edges into the next turn.
This will also allow for better early edge grip on ice and give more 
control to your turn shape.
Slow down and watch 0:38 through 0:46 and 4:34 through 4:44 to see this 
happen
comments.author: Pete Jucker

comments.text:
+Pete Jucker Really? I thought you were supposed to keep your weight mostly 
on your downhill ski, especially if its icy
comments.author: LessTraveled Gravel

comments.text: +htimsnad2793 let me know how it works for you.
comments.author: Pete Jucker

comments.text:
Great! I'll try that in 2 weeks when I'm off to Zell am See :D Thanks so 
much!
comments.author: htimsnad2793

comments.text:
Make sure you stay balanced over the inside edge of your outside ski and 
try to keep weight distribution almost even on both feet.
comments.author: Pete Jucker

comments.text:
A good How  to Ski video.
My critique: This should not be classified as an "advanced" ski lesson, but 
should be advocated as soon as the beginner is comfortable on his or her 
skiis.
The other item is, the instructor does not use a pole plant when 
demonstrating the turns, but does use pole plants when free skiing. The 
beginner/intermediate may not recognize the importance of  the pole plant 
without it being pointed out during the video.
The pole plant is very important - it sets the timing for weight and edge 
change at the beginning of the turn, and keeps the body mass forward,
Otherwise a good technical carving demo.   ﻿
